Metadata: Osmoregulation and circulating growth hormone and prolactin levels in hypophysectomiz​ed coho salmon ("Oncorhynchus kisutch") after transfer to fresh water and seawater

During smoltification, coho salmon ("Oncorhynchus kisutch") develop seawater adaptability. Hypophysectomy allows the analysis of endocrine control of ion regulation. In this study, the effects of hypophysectomy on survival, NA+, K+-ATPase activity, plasma osmolality, plasma sodium concentration and plasma levels of several hormones in seawater (SW) and in freshwater (FW) were examined in coho salmon at various times up to 7 days after transfer. Special attention was paid to the time course of response of hypophysectomiz​ed fish to FW because previous data showed that these animals survive in a hypotonic environment with little effect on plasma sodium levels and plasma osmolality.
